message_1:
Consider the following formula in the propositional calculus:

(p → (q → r)) → ((p → q) → (p → r))

Prove that this formula is a tautology using natural deduction.
message_2:
To prove that the given formula is a tautology using natural deduction, we will use the rules of inference and show that the formula is true under all possible truth assignments. The formula is:

(p → (q → r)) → ((p → q) → (p → r))

We will use the following rules of inference:

1. Implication Elimination (→E)
2. Implication Introduction (→I)

Proof:

1. Assume (p → (q → r)) (Assumption)
2. Assume (p → q) (Assumption)
3. Assume p (Assumption)
4. q → r (1, 3, →E)
5. q (2, 3, →E)
6. r (4, 5, →E)
7. p → r (3-6, →I)
8. (p → q) → (p → r) (2-7, →I)
9. (p → (q → r)) → ((p → q) → (p → r)) (1-8, →I)

Thus, we have proven that the given formula is a tautology using natural deduction.
